text:
The following
content is provided under a Creative
Commons license. Your support will help MIT
OpenCourseWare continue

to offer high-quality
educational resources for free. To make a donation or to
view additional materials

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu.

PROFESSOR: So welcome back. Today, we're going to look
at the modular synthesizer. And our area of focus
right now is still

looking at musical interfaces. A lot of people present
the modular synthesizer

in the context of basic
synthesis techniques

and the development of
musical instruments. I think it's very
useful for us to think of the modular synthesizer as
a type of musical interface,

and particularly the
interface available through the creative patching
and combination of modules.

So what we're going
to do is we're going to look at a little bit of
the history of the development of modular synthesizers,
starting with the giant RCA

synth, and then
moving on to the Moog. We're going to spend a little
time with the basic Moog design and look at some of the
basic synthesis techniques.

We're going to do
that by looking at the emulation of
virtual Moog that we

have available through
Arturia's very nice virtual Moog

instrument plug-in, which
is going to give us a way to hear some of the sounds
and see some of the approaches to patching this instrument.

And then next time we meet in
workshop mode next Tuesday, we're going to build some
similar designs in PD

using the Martingale
Library and explore some of these
approaches, as well.

We're going to listen to some
music and then if we get to it, talk about some
semi-modular synths. And see the design go from
fully modular synthesizers

to semi-modular and
non-modular synthesizers, which is a valuable trajectory to see.

So coming up on the horizon, we
have a brief quiz on Thursday. Keep that in mind. Your music technology
case studies--

the draft is due on Tuesday. If you have any questions about
this as you approach this,

feel free to drop me
an email or the like. And that's it for now.

Any questions? OK. So now with the
modular synthesizer,

we see numerous things
start to come together. We saw in the early studios
used by Varese, by Stockhausen,

and others, this cobbling
together of various components and interconnecting them
into sound-producing devices.

We see with the
modular synthesizer these components
start to solidify into a single common
collection of entities.

With these semi-modular
designs, we see this solidification
happen even more.

And the designs solidify
into a single common thing.

There wasn't anything shockingly
new about the technologies used in the modular synthesizer.

Again, they were
technologies that had been around
for 10 or 20 years. But really, the
interface, and the design,

and the integration of these
components, in my view, was the really important thing.

Voltage control-- the ability
to interconnect and control these devices with
voltages-- was really

the key technology that made
this synthesizer more flexible, more powerful, and more
creative for the operator.

Now we start with the RCA
synthesizer, which isn't really

a modular synthesizer. To my knowledge, this device
had a fairly fixed signal path.

So it wasn't really modular. It had components. But you couldn't
interconnect the components with patch cords.

You couldn't radically
change the type of sounds that it made. Now this synthesizer came
in two different forms.

There was the first one, which
later became known as the Mark I and then the Mark II,
the later version of this.

This synthesizer was the result
of quite a bit of research by Olson and Belar,
who were working

at RCA for a number of years. The Holmes text nicely
describes their early research

with music synthesis
technologies. Does anybody recall
what they were trying to do in the
beginning-- Olson and Belar.

Their first attempt
at synthesis was directed towards this
certain activity.

Anybody recall? They were trying to synthesize
Steven Walter pop tunes-- pop

melodies-- basic melodies,
using essentially Markov chains. And they were trying to
create a machine that

could compose simple melodies
by analyzing basic tunes and then re-synthesizing them.

In that process, they
developed some technologies for creating
oscillators and filters.

And that led to their
first RCA synthesizer. So this device used essentially
tuning-fork-based oscillators.

So their basic oscillator
was a tuning fork that was set in motion and
picked up electromagnetically.

And that signal was then divided
to shift into different octaves

and transformed into a square
wave to create a rich tone. And then they filtered
that tone to create

the variety of timbres that
the instrument could make.

The device featured
a number of filters, as well-- high- and low-pass
filters and this really kind

of bizarre resonator
chain, which is an interesting
selective filter.

This image here is from
their first publication on the synthesizer from 1955.

And it's also reproduced
in the Holmes book. We can see the basic way
that the synthesizer worked.

Information was encoded on
something kind of like a piano roll, but just storing
control information

in a binary representation. Here, rather than
using a vacuum, brushes are used to pick up
when an opening in the hole

was to trigger a circuit. The frequency source
here is those oscillators

controlled by tuning forks. And that signal is then
split by the octiver.

And then it has the
frequency glider, which allows the transition
between pitches, the growth,

and decay, which is a fancy
name for an envelope generator. Or not fancy, I guess--
historic-- various high-pass,

low-pass filters,
volume control, low-frequency
modulator, probably for adding vibrato or other
slow changes to the sound.

Resonator change--
that's that unique filter I was talking about--
timbre control, probably

additional filters. Or I'm not exactly sure what
that last component did. But that's something to look at.

And then finally, all going
to a nice record cutter, which allowed you
to record the sound.

So there were two
nearly identical voices that could be used and
controlled by this paper roll.

So partly out of Olson and
Belar's earlier research

in synthesizing pop tunes,
they approached a synthesizer as a device that needed to be
controlled, not by a keyboard,

not by some other
type of interface, but by a type of notation. And their notation was this
punched-hole paper record,

which again, is kind of like
a piano roll but different. Because rather than a one-to-one
relationship with parameters

and their values,
these are essentially three- and four-bit codes that
determine frequency, octave,

timbre, the envelope growth
and decay, and volume. So frequency is determined by
these four on-and-off switches,

which give us 16
possible values. But they only used 12. Octave could be selected.

Similarly here, timbre, the
envelope, volume, et cetera.

This roll right there shows
us the necessary information to encode these six pitches.

So you can imagine working
with this device would be a little tedious. But it offered explicit,
complete control.

This nice diagram, also
from that original article,

shows us a massive
simplification of the device, going from reading the
roll, to the two synthesizer

channels, mixer, amplifier, and
then a direct-to-disk cutting lathe.

Some notable thing
about this-- it was really the first
attempt to parameterize

musical information in a very
rigorous and complete way. We saw with the player
piano an earlier attempt

at parameterization. But here, we're starting
to parameterize timbre,

amplitude envelopes, and
volume and level controls at a greater degree than we
had with the player piano.

Also important about
this instrument is it was not designed
for performance. It was really designed
as a machine where

you composed in
advance and played back what you had notated.

That was the Mark
I. The Mark II was housed at Princeton University. And that started a relationship
with Columbia and Princeton

University, which led to
Columbia and Princeton getting a grant from the
Rockefeller Foundation

to buy the second version of
this synth-- the RCA Mark II.

This synth was very
similar to the Mark I, except for it added a
white-noise generator, which

was useful for creating a
variety of noisier percussive sounds.

It had four voices
instead of two. It had a microphone input. And it had some variable
frequency oscillators.

Similar to the RCA Mark I, it
was a room-sized giant beast

of a synthesizer. In this picture, we can
see the disk cutters here.

We can see, also, some tape. Eventually, they did
add tape machines. And we can see the
paper readers there.

Notice that we don't see,
really, a patch bay or patch cords. This was a modular synthesizer
in that had modules.

But it wasn't freely
interconnectable in the way that we later find with our
Moog and Buchla synthesizers.

Now I sent you guys the link
to this demo recording, which

has this great narrator
helping us along the way.

This demo record
was made in 1955. I believe it was a
recording of the Mark II.

The reason why is because
in this demonstration, they use a filtered white noise.

And I think this is a
very nice example where they tried to synthesize the
sound of a complete dance band.

So they had four voices. So they used some of the
voices for bass, percussion, and melody. Let's listen to
a little of this.

[HIGH-PITCHED SYNTHESIZER BEEPS] PROFESSOR: That's
the high-hat sound. [LOW-PITCHED SYNTHESIZER BEEPS] PROFESSOR: And that's the bass.

[SYNTHESIZER] PROFESSOR: And here's
everything altogether. [VIDEO PLAYBACK] -We can also
synthesize a part where

each tone has a rapid growth
and slow decay, like this. [END VIDEO PLAYBACK] PROFESSOR: Let's go
back to that dance band.
[LOW-PITCHED SYNTHESIZER BEEPS] PROFESSOR: Come on. [SYNTHESIZED MUSIC] PROFESSOR: There we go.

Notice the white noise being
used for the snare-like sound

there. So as this demo record shows,
and as the history of Olson

and Belar's work
shows, they were very interested in
using the synthesizer to generate pop music,
which is interesting.

Because what it became used
for was not popular music, but music of composers
like Milton Babbitt, Mario

Davidovsky, and other
composers working at the Columbia-Princeton
studios.

One of our listenings for today
was "Philomel," Babbitt's 1964 composition that used
the RCA synthesizer.

Let's listen to a
little bit of this to remind you guys
what this sounds like. [MUSIC -- MILTON BABBITT,
 "PHILOMEL"]

PROFESSOR: So
there's three sources of sound in this composition.

What are they-- three
sources of sound? AUDIENCE: There's the voice. PROFESSOR: Right,
the live voice. AUDIENCE: There's
the synthesizer.

Not sure what the third was. PROFESSOR: Anybody
notice or recall? There's also pre-recorded voice.

So there's some tape-recorded
and processed voice sounds in here, which are used to
create some very nice distance

echo and some
depth to the voice. And actually in my view, one
of the most interesting things

about this piece is
how the tape part blends with the synthesis
and acts as an intermediary.
Thoughts about this piece? AUDIENCE: It's very sporadic.

PROFESSOR: Sporadic-- what
do you mean, sporadic? AUDIENCE: Very jagged.

I don't know. It's not really-- they
follow a certain pattern. But there's not a ton of tune.

PROFESSOR: Yeah, there's this
jagged, jerky, gestural shape to a lot of the musical parts.

And that's clear in the voice
and also in the synthesizer parts. AUDIENCE: As the piece
goes on, the voice

smooths out a
little bit, though, if I remember correctly. And then the synthesizer's still
doing the jagged [INAUDIBLE].

So it has the background
interjections, I guess. It seems like longer stretches.

AUDIENCE: Yeah. PROFESSOR: Yeah, let's
jump to the end in here. [MUSIC -- MILTON BABBITT,
 "PHILOMEL"]

PROFESSOR: Now Babbitt was
using a method of organization that we have talked
about previously. What was that method
of organization?

AUDIENCE: Serialism. PROFESSOR: Serialism, or
the 12-tone technique.

Did the RCA synthesizer
provide facilities for 12-tone composers? Was it well suited for that?

I mean, Olson and Belar wanted
to use it to do popular music. AUDIENCE: You had absolute
control over everything, right?

So it was perfect. PROFESSOR: Right. All your parameters
were fixed on the roll. So you could compose very
carefully crafted lines

in a very organized way. And that's very much
what we hear here.

It's kind of, I think, ironic
in that Olson and Belar imagined this instrument
originally to create

an endless variety
of pop tunes to sell in the commercial market. And of course, it
ended up being used

to create some very esoteric,
non-commercial music

in the end. And that's one of
our many examples of unintended consequences
of certain technologies.

Other comments or
reflections on this piece? AUDIENCE: I thought
it was really cool to use the
operatic voice with it,

as opposed to other
singing styles. Because in conjunction
with the synthesizer,

the strange timbre
of operatic singing became this thing that
was more like a thing

to listen to than typically
what operatic singing is about. PROFESSOR: Yeah,
that's interesting.

For me, the really striking
thing is the vibrato. Because the vibrato
is really, really wide-- contrast between that
wide vibrato and the more flat

tones we're getting
out of the synthesizer. Are you hearing
something else, as well? AUDIENCE: No, that's
the sort of thing.

But then also in the
tape-modulated parts. Because he speeds her
up and slows her down. And so this thing happens
with the vibrato right

where they like. It was very tight, or
even looser and lower. And there's this
really, I think, great interplay between that
and the synthesized sounds.

PROFESSOR: Yeah, I agree. Yep. AUDIENCE: Yeah,
the sound I heard reminded me a lot
of science fiction.

PROFESSOR: Uh-huh. [LAUGHS] AUDIENCE: There seems
to be a common thread about that recording.

PROFESSOR: Yeah. Well, a lot of the early
sounds of early synthesizers were used in science fiction and
film, since Forbidden Planet,

and even before that
with the theremin. The connection has been
there for some time.

We don't hear a lot of
variety of timbres and colors with the synthesizer. A lot of it is sinusoidal
or filtered waveforms.

So there's not a huge variety
of sounds out of the synth. But it didn't provide a
tremendous amount of control,

as we can tell by looking
at the control information available on the tape. AUDIENCE: Do you know
anything about how

it was serialed, whether he
used all of his parameters

in the serial way? I was trying to parse it
out, and I had no idea. PROFESSOR: Yeah. I mean, it's worth
looking at further.

I suspect, given
Babbitt's inclinations, that both pitch and the other
parameters were serialized.

So it's very likely
he had the opportunity to serialize envelopes
and serialize

the timbre controls
of the synth. So I think it's very
likely that he probably did, which is similar to an
approach taken by Stockhausen,

who was rigorously exploring
some of these things. But with the RCA synthesizer,
this became very notatable

in a way that wasn't
possible before. Do you have another comment? OK. So two innovators followed
the RCA synthesizer

with devices that were
more flexible than the RCA

synthesizer. They were more flexible in
that they allowed the operator to reconnect the
modules in various ways.

Rather than that fixed sequence
of oscillator, filter, et

cetera, these devices
allowed the operator to interconnect them in a
variety of different ways

and also allowed the
operator to control them in a variety of different
ways, not with punched paper

but with various types
of input devices. Buchla generally gets credit
for coming a little bit

before Moog. His devices were very diverse
and often custom-designed

was in creating diverse
and unique instruments, not really in creating
a commercial market

for the synthesizer. So he not only explored a wide
variety of different modules

that use noise and
randomness in different ways, but also various
types of input devices

other than the keyboard. And our readings for today
emphasize the point about how

Buchla initially didn't want
a keyboard control for his instrument, and
Moog embraced that, which is an issue we'll talk
about when we talk about

the [? Pinchen-Trocho ?]
reading. In 1965, he releases
the Buchla Box

without a keyboard-- a
very popular instrument. 1970, he has this 200
series Electric Music Box,

which you can see there. Also doesn't have a
keyboard, but has a variety of sliders, knobs, and
other interface components.

In the '70s, he released
some portable devices. This one, although apparently I
think Holmes says that only 200

of these were made-- wouldn't
you like one of these?

He did use a keyboard at times. But notice that this is a
touch-sensitive keyboard

and probably does some
things we wouldn't expect. A small, portable
modular synthesizer--

if you can find one
of these, get it. [LAUGHS] Buchla is still
making synthesizers. They're very expensive.

But they really offer
some unique designs. Looking at his designs--
you can go to his website--

are really fascinating, creative
approaches to the synthesizer.

Buchla is a separate
thread from that of Moog. Because Moog's instruments
were dedicated to meeting the

needs-- the demands--
of musicians. Our readings make
that very clear. He worked with musicians
in a variety of ways.

He invited musicians
to come to his factory and explore his instruments. He adapted his instruments
to the demands of musicians

in order to meet their needs,
and really, through that, made a very successful
commercial instrument.

Now we've already
talked about how Moog got started with
the theremin as a kid, creating theremin
kits in his garage.

In 1954, he published this
article in Radio and Television News about his design for
a tube-based theremin.

This article's great. You can check it out online. It also has the whole schematic
diagram for the circuit.

At this time in
the '40s and '50s, there was this whole
kit-bit building culture,

and a lot of interest
in building theremin. So his design
became very popular

and attracted a
lot of attention. He published another
article in 1961

using a transistor-based
theremin that was actually featured on the cover
of this magazine and also got him a
lot of attention.

He, by then, had a business. He and his dad were selling
theremins out of their garage--

theremin kits. By the '60s, he meets a
composer by the name of Deutsch,

who knew Moog because
of the theremin-- his theremin kits-- and
wanted to know about, well,

if he can do some other types
of synthesizing devices-- some other types of
devices that allowed

you to take basic oscillators,
interconnect them, and put them under flexible control.

Moog develops his first
synthesizer, the 900 Series, in 1965.

This device wasn't
distributed broadly. It was used mostly by
composers and some studios.

In 1966, he patents
his low-pass filter, which becomes a very important
part of his synthesizer.

Because it allowed to take
a rich, wide bandwidth

sound and control its timbre
and give it a very crisp tone.

We'll hear some of that
sound very shortly. People say that this was the
only thing that Moog patented.

But there are some other patents
associated with the Moog name. It was definitely the first
device that he patented.

And the low-pass filter
was novel in that it had a particularly
steep roll-off curve.

So it was able to really focus
the sound underneath the cutoff frequency. And it had an
adjustable resonance,

which provided a nice peak
at that cutoff frequency. Now it's in 1967
that he releases

his first real commercial
product, the series Systems 1,

2, and 3. This is an earlier device. We can see with this
one, the keyboard.

We can see some of
the basic modules. And we can see, also, a ribbon
controller, another type

of input device
that he explored. This got later
refined into devices

of this sort, which
is very often what we see when we imagine
the Moog synthesizer. Here we have a number of
oscillators, filters, up here.

And this over here
is a sequencer, which we're actually going
to talk about sequencing next time we meet-- also,
the keyboard and the ribbon

controller, as well. So with the Systems
1, 2, and 3 in 1967,

there was some standard
packages you could buy. But you could still
buy individual modules

for your own synthesizer. And this nice
price list shows us

some of the prices
of these devices. We could get a
voltage-controlled amplifier

for $150-- fair price. That voltage-controlled
low-pass, high-pass filter,
$475 for one filter in 1968.

That's pretty expensive. These synthesizers were
extremely expensive.

But they started to be
sold and commercialized. And people started to buy them. But one thing in particular led
to the explosion of the Moog

industry, and that was Wendy
Carlos's Switched-on Bach recording, recorded in
1968, released in '69,

and garnered a huge
amount of attention to the Moog synthesizer. We'll talk about Wendy
Carlos and her recording

in a little bit. But let's review
some of the concepts of the modular synthesizer.

So we have two basic components. We have things that
generate sound, like our oscillators
and other devices.

And we have components
that modify those sounds. So we have these
two different types

of modules that can be
interconnected and modified. The input four module
is either the knobs

on the front panel
or another voltage. And some devices
allow you to switch between using the knob
or a voltage as an input,

or using both-- using the
knob to set a basic level and then the input voltage
to adjust it further.

The output of these
modules is another voltage, which can be interconnected to
modules further down the line.

Within the modular synthesizer,
we have two types of signals. We have control signals
and audio signals.

Both of these,
depending on the design, can be interconnected
in various ways. Audio signals are
the things that we're

used to-- sounds represented
as a bipolar voltage.

Voltage ranges would generally
between negative 3 and 3 volts. Sometimes higher or wider
ranges were possible.

Control signals were also
voltages but generally unipolar voltages between maybe
0 and plus 5 volts.

These were often
more slowly moving signals that could
be used to control the parameters of
another module.

Control signals were used,
obviously, to shape envelopes. And these envelopes
could be applied

to parameters other than
the amplitude of the sound, such as a cutoff
frequency or the like.

Now a key concept of
the modular synthesizer was the ability to
reuse the modules.

We could use an oscillator
to produce a tone and hear that tone
of the oscillator.

We could also use an
oscillator to shape the amplitude of a sound
and produce a tremolo,

or to modulate the frequency
of another oscillator and produce a vibrato, or use
the output of an oscillator

to modulate the cutoff
frequency to create a variable timbre to a sound. I'm going to demonstrate
all of those in a second.

This ability to reuse these
modules-- to mix audio signals

and control signals and
transform one to the other-- was really the key feature
of the modular synthesizer,

combined with voltage
control, and gave it a great degree of flexibility.

Now in this golden age of
the modular synthesizer, when you sat down
to this instrument,

you got nothing for free. You sat down. It didn't make any sound. In order to make a sound, you
had to design an instrument.

So the interface, in order to
make a sound, became patching. You had to patch
to make a sound.

No sounds were given to you. And this promoted a huge degree
of freedom and creativity

in the design of sounds. We see, over the
history of synthesizers, this start to decrease.

And so in the late '60s is
when we have the most freedom. And as the '70s move
on, we see synthesizers

that reduce the
ability of patching and make it easier to get
a sound more automatically.

And then by the early
'80s, we have synthesizers that are programmable but
have very little in terms
of a customizable interface.

Some of the basic components
of the synthesizer-- these are screenshots
of virtual synths,

which is kind of amusing. But they allow us
to see more clearly some of the designs
of these synthesizers.

So our basic oscillators, or
voltage-control oscillators, generally provided a
control for frequency.

Often, the range of
the frequency knob would be variable in steps. So we have a dedicated
low-frequency switch

for low-frequency oscillators. And then we have
various higher ranges, which use the terminology
derived from organs--

32 foot, 16 foot, 8
foot, and the like. We had the ability to
get different waveforms

from the same
oscillator, which is a nice convenience
of such devices.

We have various noise sources,
and we'll hear example of those

as well. And we have a sample on
hold generators, which allow us to take an input signal
and sample it periodically

to create a stepped shape. I'll demonstrate that in
a little bit, as well.

Now our modular
synthesizers usually had some sort of mixing
control-- some ability to combine signals.

And this sometimes was under
control of another voltage. So we have voltage-control
amplifiers, or VCAs.

Sometimes we have
mixers that use various toggles or
on-off switches. This is from the design
of the Minimoog, where

the various oscillators had
a level control and then a toggle switch. And some devices
had various types

of matrix-mixing and
patching controls, which are very, very cool.

This EMS synthesizer--
the Synthi, Synth-I-- allowed you to control
the routing of signals, rather

than through patch
cords through a matrix. This was a template
used to help you

remember your patch
with this synth. These synths are very cool. If you can find one, grab it.
Notice the convenient handle. You can take it with you.

All of our synthesizers have
various types of filters. A VCF, or
voltage-control filter,

allows you to adjust
the parameters with a voltage, the low-pass
filter and high-pass filter

being the most common,
a band-pass filter and other varieties also found.

In our modular synthesizer,
we have various types of envelope generators. The envelope is
a unipolar signal

that we can apply to the
amplitude of a sound. But we can also
apply the envelope to other musical parameters.

The key thing about an
envelope is its control signal that's designed to be triggered.

It's a control signal
that's designed to start at a certain
time and end, as opposed to something like a
low-frequency oscillator that

is continuous and ongoing. The ADSR is probably
the most common type

of envelope control on these
early modular synthesizers, although there were
other varieties, as well.

There was AR filters and
attack-decay-sustain filters--

various simplifications
of the ADSR model.

The key approach to using
the modular synthesizer at this time is often called
subtractive synthesis.

The idea of
subtractive synthesis is we start with a
rich, complex tone, and we use our filters to
take away from that tone

and get the sound
that we're looking at. This is part of the reason
why Moog's low-pass filter was so important.

Because we could start with
a complex tone and then use the low-pass filter to
shape out the frequencies

that we did not want.  So our basic approach of
working in subtractive synthesis

would be to start with
a rich complex tone, to cut out some of
those frequencies, apply amplitude
envelopes to vary

the amplitude shape
of that sound, and then use modulation
to vary the parameters.

And this starts to
become really interesting when we modulate the modulators. And we'll listen to what
that sounds like in a second.

Questions, comments, ideas? OK. So let's hear what
this sounds like.

Now probably the most
basic approach on one of the most common approaches
to creating a complex sound

would be combining
multiple oscillators. And this design is embodied
in some of the early Moog

synthesizers, where we
have three oscillators--

like these three oscillators
right here-- all under one driver to control the
three oscillators.

The idea embodied
in the interface here is that we're
going to create a rich tone by
combining oscillators.

We can tune each of
these oscillators to different octaves and
slight tuning differences.

But they're all going to
be under a single control. Let's listen to what
this sounds like.

So our first example-- if we
start off with just a single
oscillator-- [LOW-PITCH SYNTHESIZER TONES]

So here, we're hearing
a sawtooth waveform. And I'm taking it
from this oscillator

here and just dropping it
over into my big ADSR envelope there. If we want to hear a sign
tone, we can just replace that.
[SYNTHESIZER]

That's it. A strong sign tone. And we have our
triangle waveform here.
[SYNTHESIZER BEATS]

Our triangle waveform
sounds dead at that range. [SYNTHESIZER BEATS AND TONE]
That's unexpected.

Now something totally
different comes to us from the Netherlands. And this is a composition
by Gottfried Michael Koenig,

a German composer who had
been living and working in the Netherlands. And he was the artistic
director of a place called

the Institute of Sonology,
first in Utrecht and now in the Hague, where
they had over a period

of a number of years, developed
their own modular synthesizer from scratch.

So while Moog led to the
first commercial packaged synthesizer, many
people were developing

custom-built synthesizers
that looked something like this, where you have
numerous individual components

often custom designed,
scattered around the room, and a giant patch bay to
connect them all together.

This synthesizer is
still in existence. In fact, I took this
photo five years ago.

This isn't historical. It looks like that still. And it sounds fantastic. It's an amazing-sounding
synthesizer.

His composition that we
listened to-- "Gray Function," is how it translates-- is part
of a series of function pieces

that explored automating
some of the parameters of the modular synthesizer
using a single control

voltage as a pattern
that was applied to numerous different parameters
of a synthesis system.

We can hear a little bit of

 KOENIG, "GRAY FUNCTION"]

Now this piece was

Sonology synthesizer also

features a number

to be controlled by a
low-frequency oscillator or something else,
which allows you

to create series of
dynamic envelopes.
